Today, Special Counsel Robert Mueller made it crystal clear that he did not clear the president of criminal activity.

He also said "the Constitution requires a process other than the criminal justice system to formally accuse a sitting president.”

Impeachment is that process. https://twitter.com/RepValDemings/status/1130948548596523008 …

Today is a big news day (Mueller saying he wasn't allowed to charge the president with a crime, for example), but it's important to remember that a new study showed that the #GOPTaxScam gave a trillion dollars to big corporations while working families got almost nothing.

Think about this fact: Special Counsel Mueller spent two years on his investigation. In that entire time and after, he has made almost no public statements.

So why did he go on TV today? Because he wanted to be crystal clear: the president was not cleared of criminal activity. pic.twitter.com/1u6bs8ESeU

My full statement:
 https://demings.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-demings-mueller-reaction … pic.twitter.com/Qg3lubWH8M

 https://demings.house.gov/media/press-releases/rep-demings-mueller-reaction … pic.twitter.com/8CyLYMWTdA

Hi Phil, that's actually the opposite of what he said. 

“If we had confidence that the president did NOT commit a crime, we would have said so."

In other words, it's possible the president committed a crime, but they weren't allowed to consider charging him under DOJ rules.

To be clear, the Special Counsel explains this explicitly in his report. But for him to go on television and repeat it adds new urgency, putting it front & center before Congress & the American people. He's asking us to do what he wasn't allowed to—hold the president accountable. https://twitter.com/jimsciutto/status/1133751725804916737 …

Special Counsel Robert Mueller just said that "charging the president with a crime was not an option we could consider" under DOJ policy.

It wasn't lack of evidence. It was DOJ policy.

He said that this "deserves the attention of every American." He's right. Congress must act.
